extendedIngredients.name: jalapeno pepper
extendedIngredients.original: 1 to 2 teaspoons minced fresh jalapeno pepper, to taste (1 pepper)
extendedIngredients.originalName: minced fresh jalapeno pepper, to taste (1 pepper)

extendedIngredients.name: mangos
extendedIngredients.original: 2 ripe mangos, peeled, seeded, and small diced
extendedIngredients.originalName: ripe mangos, peeled, seeded, and small diced

extendedIngredients.name: olive oil
extendedIngredients.original: 2 tablespoons good olive oil, plus extra for searing
extendedIngredients.originalName: good olive oil, plus extra for searing

title: Seared Tuna with Mango Salsa
summary: The recipe Seared Tuna with Mango Salsa could satisfy your Mexican craving in around 1 hour. One portion of this dish contains approximately 43g of protein, 23g of fat, and a total of 556 calories. This recipe serves 2. For $7.64 per serving, this recipe covers 42% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. It works well as an expensive main course. It is a good option if you're following a gluten free, dairy free, and pescatarian diet. If you have garlic, mint leaves, mangos, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the olive oil you could follow this main course with the Sauteed Banana, Granolan and Yogurt Parfait as a dessert. 1 person found this recipe to be delicious and satisfying. It is brought to you by Foodnetwork. With a spoonacular score of 85%, this dish is outstanding. Try Seared Tuna with Japanese Salsa, Seared Tuna With Japanese Salsa, and Seared Tuna with Pineapple Salsa for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Merlot, Pinot Noir, and rosé Wine are my top picks for Tuna. Though fish is often paired with white wine, 'meatier' fish like tuna can absolutely go with red wine. A Rosé will also pair nicely, particularly if your tunan is prepared with ingredients better suited to a white wine. One wine you could try is Matanzas Creek Alexander Valley Merlot. It has 4.3 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 28 dollars.

productMatches.title: Matanzas Creek Alexander Valley Merlot
productMatches.description: A medium purple color. Flavors of satsuma plum, dark chocolate covered raspberries, and allspice aromas primarily. On the palate, this is a classic Merlot with good concentration. It is savory and medium bodied with velvety tannins. Homemade cherry pie tart and sandal wood aromas are perceived easily when tasting.

instructions: Watch how to make this recipe.                    Saute the olive oil, onions, and ginger in a large saute pan over medium-low heat for 10 minutes, or until the onions are translucent. Add the garlic and cook for 1 more minute. Add the mangos, reduce the heat to low and cook for 10 more minutes. Add the orange juice, brown sugar, salt, black pepper, and jalapeno; cook for 10 more minutes, until orange juice is reduced, stirring occasionally. Remove from the heat and add the mint. Serve warm, at room temperature, or chilled.                          Heat a saute pan over high heat for 5 minutes until very hot. Season the tuna liberally with salt and pepper. When the pan is very hot, add a drizzle of olive oil and then the tuna steaks. Sear for 2 to 3 minutes on each side, or until the outside is browned, but the inside is very rare.                          Serve the tuna on top of the mango salsa.

steps.step: Watch how to make this recipe.
Saute the olive oil, onions, and ginger in a large saute pan over medium-low heat for 10 minutes, or until the onions are translucent.
Add the garlic and cook for 1 more minute.
Add the mangos, reduce the heat to low and cook for 10 more minutes.
Add the orange juice, brown sugar, salt, black pepper, and jalapeno; cook for 10 more minutes, until orange juice is reduced, stirring occasionally.
Remove from the heat and add the mint.
Serve warm, at room temperature, or chilled.

Heat a saute pan over high heat for 5 minutes until very hot. Season the tuna liberally with salt and pepper. When the pan is very hot, add a drizzle of olive oil and then the tuna steaks. Sear for 2 to 3 minutes on each side, or until the outside is browned, but the inside is very rare.
Serve the tuna on top of the mango salsa.
